text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.

I'm Aley Hammer, and today
we're interviewing Nick Andrews,
the CTO at Origin Energy.

Nick, thank you so much
for joining us today.
I wanted to begin by asking you
what was it that prompted Origin

to actually look at a cloud
journey in the first place?
- Oh, Origin Energy

is the biggest energy
provider in Australia.
We've got over 4 million customers.

We provide energy services,
generation services.
We also have renewable business,

and we mine and export
gas all around the world,
so we're a largest business,
and we're on the Australian Stock Market.
We've grown dramatically.
We're 20 years old.

We grew through lots of
acquisitions and lots of growth
the first 15 years of our business,
and what we realized after that time is
we had an IT Department that was built
through growth and acquisition,
and was sort of come together
in a sort of rapid growth environment,
but it wasn't as organized and structured,

and had become quite
disconnected from our business.
And what we also found
was that we suddenly reached a situation
in 2015, and again in 2018,

and we were faced with quite
significant business pressures,
and in that, there was an immediate need
for the business to respond,
to reduce costs and become more efficient,
and our IT was asked to be part of that,
and what we found is

we just couldn't make
the changes necessary,
we couldn't keep pace with our business,
that at the same time,
we had inherited a lot of legacy systems
with a lot of out-of-date technology
that needed improvement and modernizing,
and that was causing a lot of instability
and a lot of problems operationally.
So we had two big problems.
We couldn't meet our cost objectives,
we couldn't give a stable service,

and our relationship with
our business colleagues
was just not as it should be,

and it was affecting the
way we deliver service
to our customers.

- Well, there are so
many great reasons now,

and it sounds like it
was just the right time
to make the move to the cloud.

And Nick, Origin has
achieved huge cost savings,
as you've mentioned,
and benefits along the way,

and I wanted you to share
some of those benefits,
'cause the stats are quite mind-boggling.

- Yeah, they are, and surprising
to all of us, actually,
as we did...

We set about this journey
in building a strategy
a broader IT strategy,
but the key foundation of that strategy

was what we call Cloud
2022, or 100% in the cloud.
We started that, actually, in 2017, 2018,
and it was on the back of these challenges
that we had as a business,
and it has been a great success,

and we have successfully
moved all our workloads
to cloud, now,
we're a 100% cloud business.
It's been a wonderful journey,
a very challenging journey.

I think the benefits
have been, as we said,
quite surprising.

First of all, a lot of
people talk about cost,
cost has been a huge benefit to us.

We've seen about a 50% cost
reduction across our estate
by moving to cloud.
What we also have seen

is what I call the
clean-up-the-garage philosophy.
We've seen the opportunity

to actually clean up
our application estate
and to get things right during this time,

and we were able to remove
almost half our applications
in that time,

which actually has
contributed dramatically
to both the savings

and the very impressive
operational stability.
We've seen more than a 500% improvement
in operations and stability,

which obviously makes our
business really happy,

and makes our customers
(chuckles) even happier,

'cause the systems they use
every day just work for them.

Complementing that has been
a whole lot of other benefits

we probably didn't
think were gonna happen.

We've had significant
security improvement,

because we didn't have visibility
when it was on-premise,
we just didn't have transparency.
Now we've got amazing transparency
across all our applications and systems,
and we know what's going on in real time,
and it allows us to respond,

and we've been really
successful in responding,
with greater uplift in security.
Our speed has increased.

It was so slow to
provision, compute, storage.
It would take us weeks, months.

Now, everything's measured
in hours and minutes.
I can't even remember what it was like,
but it is a big change.

The other ones have been
sort of complementary.
We've been able to change our workforce.
Along the journey, we've moved

from a model where everything
was centralized in IT
to actually pushing empowerment back

closer to our business
colleagues, closer to people

who actually deal with
our customers every day.
There's a much greater ability
for them to respond to customer needs
and to respond to business change.
We've seen more technical people
across the whole of our business,
increase, as we've done the cloud journey.

It's also enabled us to
have some cultural changes,
like more agile working
and more practices that just move at pace,
which is what we had to do
to compete in the market that we're in.
- Wow, I mean, let me just digest this.
You said 50% cost savings,
500% improvement in operation stability.
Holy moly, when you're talking
you're making me smile,
because I can just see it's so genuine,

and I'm really glad that it
was worth it for you guys.
I mean, before this role,
I've been at Amazon a couple of years now,

and I was in a sales role,
and we literally were told
to call our customers, and reduce bills,
and help them cut costs,

so I really have seen
the other side of that,

and I'm so glad to see a
customer reaping the benefits
and being so pleased with the move.
- Yep.
- So I wanna ask you,
what's it actually like to work at Origin
in terms of your culture and people?

'Cause I've heard amazing
things about your,
well, sorry, not your industry,
actually, your business,
and I just wanna hear a little bit
around the people and the culture,

and what it's like since you
made the jump to the cloud.
- I mean, to be honest with you,

our industry, it's going
through a massive transition.
It's a very exciting place, actually,
as we go through the energy transition,
and Origin's really focused on that.
We have got a big journey to focus
to a renewable-orientated business,

and even more customer-orientated,
with diverse products,
and Origin, like most businesses,

has gone through a
massive cultural journey

to try and be the company
where people really wanna work,

and I have enjoyed
seeing a dramatic change
in my time at Origin.

We have moved to a business
that's so values-driven,
we've got these core values
at the heart of our business,

through our CEO and through
their leadership team,

and from those values, all
our decisions are made.
That is being a fundamental change,

and it allows us to make
great, thoughtful decisions,
it allows us to make timely decisions,

and it makes ones that,
actually, sometimes,
that are not always intuitive,
but they hold to a set of principles
that actually keep us consistent.
It's collaborative.

I would say that Origin's
not too, big not too small,

I've worked for some very
big global organizations,
and people are approachable,
and I think that's what you like.
You feel like you're actually connected
with the purpose of the organization,
and you actually have a voice,

and actually can talk to people
who are making decisions,

or you're part of the
decision-making process.

I also think there's a greater
sense of ownership and pride.

I really feel like we've really
changed as an organization,
and we're proud of where we're going.

I think tackling the
whole renewable journey

is something that's a
socially important area,
and we're obviously leading in that area.

The other area of things
cultural, I think,

is we've become a technically
innovative business.

Previously, technology
was just a useful tool,
when I first arrived,
but now it's become the heart
of us differentiating in our business.
We use it to differentiate
how our customers experience us digitally,
we use it to drive better production,

and the way that we get
gas out of the ground
and electricity's produced.
We use it to keep ourselves safe.
So if you love technology,
technology's been embraced,
and with that is the innovation
and a real customer focus.
We've moved to a thing called,
what we call Raving Fans Measure,
so we now measure our customers
on how much they rave about us,
how much they wanna talk about us,
and how much they recommend us,
which is a great change.

So there's a real focus
on getting it right
for our customers,

and I love those changes,
it's been wonderful.
- Well, it sounds like you've got
a pretty incredible culture,
and I really do genuinely love
that Origin is so customer-focused,
it's very similar to AWS.

And one thing that I
really notice about Origin,

working with you guys over
the last couple of years, is

when a challenge is faced,
you guys, instead of...

You're just innovative,
and you embrace it,

and like, sustainability,
and cutting costs
with moving to the cloud,

all these things, instead
of being barriers,
you've actually embraced them,
and that's pretty cool to see.

And I love that you're saying
it's quite a flat organization

'cause that's something
that's pretty important
to me, as well.
So Nick, what on earth is next for Origin?

Because you guys have already
undergone an all-in migration.
That's huge.
You said you're 100% cloud.
So is there gonna be a focus
on modernization, innovation?
Like, where are you guys heading next?
- Yeah, that's great,
and we asked ourselves this question

about, I don't know,
nine months ago, a year,
and said, well, what do we wanna do next?
What's our business need to do.
And there are things
that we just need to just keep doing well,
just don't give anyone an excuse.

You've gotta keep operating
better every week, every year,
and operationally, it needs to be stable.

We need to be more secure
than we've ever been,

and we need to keep getting
faster and more responsive.
So those things are just a given.
I think on top of that is
we have committed as a strategy

to do whole modernization,
application modernization.
When we moved our workloads the cloud,
we did not lift and shift.
We didn't do that.

We realized that wasn't
gonna be successful,

so we did do a lot of really
proactive transformation.
We updated versions,
we improved the technology currency.
We actually put in a lot of automation.

But we realized that that was
just our first opportunity,

and we've now started
looking at our business,
and said, actually, there's a way

to actually improve our
business processes more
with technology,
there's a way to uplift

the way applications can
service more effectively
across our whole organization.

There is still modernization,
particularly...
Technology doesn't stop.

So we started this journey
three or four years ago.

What we put in then, actually,
has changed dramatically.

AWS is constantly releasing
new products to market,

I struggle to keep up with
them most of the time,
and we really wanna take advantage

of those new capabilities
coming to market.
The other...

I guess, the other
thing, just quickly, is,

we also got obsessed with
automation everywhere
and the whole digitization story,

and we're seeing that push
even further into our business,
not just in the traditional IT,

but we're a big engineering,
mining business,
we're seeing that push now, also,
into our OT, our IoT-type capabilities,

so that actually, in the
industrial side of our business,

technology, automation,
and cloud capabilities
are starting to have a real impact.

- Origin is so lucky to
have you as their CTO.

It's really clear that
you love what you do,

you love technology,
and you love your job,

so I think it's amazing what
you guys have achieved with us,
and thank you so much for choosing AWS
to partner with you guys,

and we just cannot wait
to continue the journey.

So if anyone does have any
questions for Origin or myself,

please pop them in the
comment section below,
and we'll get back to you.
Thank you so much.
